prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 continuum detection of the circum-planetary disk around FU Tau b
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The aim of this program is to obtain continuum measurements of six substellar/planetary companions to young stars at 880 microns. The companions are known to have subdisks, but they have not been previously detected in continuum emission. The desired sensitivity will enable detections of disks as low as 0.1% of the companion mass at 3 sigma, therefore each target has a different desired sensitivity level. The required angular resolution to separate disks around the primary stars and the companions varies from target to target, with a range of 0.05" to 2". Coarse velocity resolution at 645 GHz will enable a serendipitous CO 3-2 detection in the companion and/or primary should it be there.
Note: for FU Tau, the coordinates are for the companion ("FU Tau b"), which is 5.7" from the primary FU Tau A. For this system we require a minimum angular resolution of 1.9" to separate the primary and companion.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our correlator setup in dual polarization mode is straightforward for these observations: since these are primarily continuum detections we propose three broad continuum windows with maximum bandwidth (1.875 GHz) and an additional 0.938 GHz window with enough resolution (0.488 MHz; 0.4 km/s) to finely sample the CO 3-2 line at 375.796 GHz. This modification from four 1.875 GHz continuum channels only increases the on-source exposure time by about 2 minutes per target, but offers the possibility to serendipitously study gas kinematics in the primary and companion disks.

To separate disk emission between the host star and companion, which ranges from 0.1" to 5.7" for targets in our sample, we require a resolution of ~1/3 of the pairs' separation. This therefore varies from target to target and is summarized in Table 1 of the Science Justification.

Our science goals can be met in any band and configuration giving adequate angular resolution (see Table 1 of Science Justification). However, Bands 8 and 9 have the smallest fraction of available time, while Bands 3 and 4 are the least sensitive to warm dust for a given integration time. To reach our 3-sigma dust mass limits, the total time requests for this program are about twice as long in Band 6 compared to Band 7. The latter therefore makes most efficient use of ALMA time.
With standard assumptions about the origin of sub-mm emission in disks (i.e., that the emission arises from optically thin, isothermal regions with known dust opacity), a dust mass can be computed from a single sub-mm flux density measurement. Our sensitivity limits are derived for a 3-sigma detection assuming a disk temperature of 15 K; a total disk-to-planet mass ratio of 0.1-0.2%, which is below the median disk-to-star mass ratio of 0.3% in Taurus (Andrews et al. 2013); a distance between 120-165 pc for our targets, and a dust opacity of kappa_0.88mm = 0.034 cm^2/g (Beckwith et al. 1990). To achieve our science goals and avoid being dominated by overheads, we require a 1-sigma rms bewteen 0.048-0.071 mJy (which varies from target to target). This is achieved with on-source integration times between 9-31 minutes for systems in our sample.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 continuum detection of the circum-planetary disk around 2M0441b
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The aim of this program is to obtain continuum measurements of six substellar/planetary companions to young stars at 880 microns. The companions are known to have subdisks, but they have not been previously detected in continuum emission. The desired sensitivity will enable detections of disks as low as 0.1% of the companion mass at 3 sigma, therefore each target has a different desired sensitivity level. The required angular resolution to separate disks around the primary stars and the companions varies from target to target, with a range of 0.05" to 2". Coarse velocity resolution at 645 GHz will enable a serendipitous CO 3-2 detection in the companion and/or primary should it be there.
Note: for 2M0441, we require a minimum angular resolution of 0.05" to separate the primary and companion.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our correlator setup in dual polarization mode is straightforward for these observations: since these are primarily continuum detections we propose three broad continuum windows with maximum bandwidth (1.875 GHz) and an additional 0.938 GHz window with enough resolution (0.488 MHz; 0.4 km/s) to finely sample the CO 3-2 line at 375.796 GHz. This modification from four 1.875 GHz continuum channels only increases the on-source exposure time by about 2 minutes per target, but offers the possibility to serendipitously study gas kinematics in the primary and companion disks.

To separate disk emission between the host star and companion, which ranges from 0.1" to 5.7" for targets in our sample, we require a resolution of ~1/3 of the pairs' separation. This therefore varies from target to target and is summarized in Table 1 of the Science Justification. In the case of 2M0441, the planetary companion is located at 0.1" from its host (a brown dwarf). This requires a long baseline setup to resolve the pair.

Our science goals can be met in any band and configuration giving adequate angular resolution (see Table 1 of Science Justification). However, Bands 8 and 9 have the smallest fraction of available time, while Bands 3 and 4 are the least sensitive to warm dust for a given integration time. To reach our 3-sigma dust mass limits, the total time requests for this program are about twice as long in Band 6 compared to Band 7. The latter therefore makes most efficient use of ALMA time.
With standard assumptions about the origin of sub-mm emission in disks (i.e., that the emission arises from optically thin, isothermal regions with known dust opacity), a dust mass can be computed from a single sub-mm flux density measurement. Our sensitivity limits are derived for a 3-sigma detection assuming a disk temperature of 15 K; a total disk-to-planet mass ratio of 0.1-0.2%, which is below the median disk-to-star mass ratio of 0.3% in Taurus (Andrews et al. 2013); a distance between 120-165 pc for our targets, and a dust opacity of kappa_0.88mm = 0.034 cm^2/g (Beckwith et al. 1990). To achieve our science goals and avoid being dominated by overheads, we require a 1-sigma rms bewteen 0.048-0.071 mJy (which varies from target to target). This is achieved with on-source integration times between 9-31 minutes for systems in our sample.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 continuum detection of the circum-planetary disk around GQ Lup

The companions are known to have subdisks, but they have not been previously detected in continuum emission. To separate disk emission between the host star and companion, which ranges from 0.1" to 5.7" for targets in our sample, we require a resolution of ~1/3 of the pairs' separation. This therefore varies from target to target and is summarized in Table 1 of the Science Justification.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 CO 3-2 Keplerian motion for FW Tau b
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of this observation is to spatially and kinematically resolve CO 3-2 to measure a dynamical mass for the candidate protoplanet FW Tau b. To spatially resolve the subdisk we require 0.1" angular resolution and to kinematically resolve it with an adequate precision to distinguish a ~50 Mjup brown dwarf versus a ~10 Mjup planet, we

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our correlator setup in dual polarization mode is divided into three continuum windows with maximum bandwidth (1.875 GHz) and an additional 0.468 GHz window with enough resolution (0.244 MHz) to adequately sample the CO 3-2 line at 375.796 GHz, as driven by the required velocity precition per channel of ~0.2 km/s.

The aim of this science goal is to spatially (and kinematically) resolve the disk around FW Tau b. Assuming a tidally truncated circum-planetary disk radius of 1/3 R_Hill, or ~30 AU, this measurement requires an angular resolution of ~0.1" in order to provide enough beams (~6) to measure Keplerian rotation in the CO 3-2 line.

It is possible to perform this measurement in Bands 6 and 7 using either the CO 2-1 or CO 3-2 lines. However, since we will also measure continuum emission with three of the four windows, this would duplicate part of the previous observation in Band 6 (Kraus et al. 2015). An additional continuum measurement in Band 7 enables a spectral index measurement to also analyze grain grown in FW Tau b's subdisk.
The CO 3-2 line intensity has not been measured in FW Tau b but we can leverage previous typical results for the Taurus brown dwarf 2M0444 (Ricci et al. 2014), for which the Band 6 continuum flux density (9.0 mJy) is roughly twice that of FW Tau b (Andrews & Williams 2005; Kraus et al. 2015). Given the vigorous accretion onto FW Tau b and several other planetary-mass companions (Bowler et al. 2014; Zhou et al. 2014), the gas mass and hence CO 3-2 emission line flux is likely to scale in the similar fashion as the continuum. With this assumption, FW Tau b will have a CO emission line flux of ~0.5 Jy km/s. Assuming a typical line width of ~3 km/s, the corresponding total flux density of the line is ~0.17 Jy. For spatially unresolved observations, we therefore would detect CO emission at 15-20 sigma per channel, allowing detailed modeling of the spectral line shape. Note that these estimates are consistent with scaling the CO 2-1 emission line flux for FW Tau b (73 mJy) recently measured by Caceros et al. (2015) with ALMA by a factor of ~2.5 following Williams & Best (2014).
Spatially resolved observations of FW Tau b will further divide the flux among multiple beams, offering the opportunity to measure the first dynamical mass in the planetary regime. Since the mass of FW Tau b may be planetary (~5-15 Mjup) or in the brown dwarf regime (~20-70 Mjup) if it has an edge-on disk, the primary goal of this measurement is to distinguish these scenarios. Given the resolution of 0.1" and the expected size of the disk (~30 AU in radius, or ~0.2"), the flux will be divided among 6 beams, yielding a flux density of 30 mJy/beam. A >4-sigma detection of the line in each channel requires an rms sensitivity of ~7 mJy/beam/channel. If the line width at a given radius is ~1 km/s, then we expect to obtain a >10 sigma detection in each channel with the ability to measure the line center to ~0.1 km/s in each beam. The Keplerian circular orbital velocity at R~30 AU (2 beams) is 1.2 km/s for a 50 Mjup brown dwarf or 0.55 km/s for a 10 Mjup planet. These data will therefore easily distinguish these possibilities at the 10-sigma level.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Circum-planetary disks are natural outcomes of giant planet formation but are observationally difficult to study. Fortunately, a handful of wide-separation (>100 AU) planetary-mass companions have recently been discovered around young stars with adaptive optics imaging, enabling the first investigations of the formation and environments of young giant planets. Early ALMA results point to a diverse range of masses and evolutionary states for these subdisks. Here we propose 880 micron continuum observations of six young substellar companions that themselves harbor disks to assess the diversity, demographics, and evolution of subdisks as a population. By increasing the sample by a factor of three we will also constrain the formation of these objects by distinguishing planet-planet scattering from disk instability or cloud fragmentation. Finally, we will measure the dynamical mass of the candidate protoplanet FW~Tau~b through CO~3-2 line emission. If its low mass (5-15 Mjup) is confirmed, this will be the first mass measurement for a directly imaged planet, indicating that the same accretion and outflow processes that occur among young stars also operate in the planetary regime.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Cycle 2 Code: 2013.1.00487.S Title: Characterizing the Circum-Planetary Disk of GSC 6214-210 b with ALMA PI: Brendan Bowler
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology
